            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-138563-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>In early 2024 we conducted a security assessment of a Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system named ICONICS Suite and identified five vulnerabilities in versions 10.97.2 and earlier for Microsoft Windows. We coordinated with the ICONICS security team, which released multiple <a href="https://iconics.com/en-us/About/Security/CERT" target="_blank" rel="noopener">security patches</a> in 2024 to resolve some of these issues and published timely security advisories with workarounds for the rest.</p>
<p>Table 1 shows the five vulnerabilities.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 17.8571%;"><b>CVE Identifier</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 68.937%;"><b>Vulnerability Description</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 12.3754%;"><b>Score</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 17.8571%;"><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-1182" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">CVE-2024-1182</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 68.937%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">DLL Hijacking in Memory Master Configuration (MMCFG) leading to Elevation of privileges.</span></td>
<td style="width: 12.3754%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">7.0 - High</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 17.8571%;"><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-7587" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">CVE-2024-7587</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 68.937%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Incorrect Default Permissions vulnerability in GenBroker32, included in the installers for ICONICS GENESIS64 version 10.97.3 and prior, Mitsubishi Electric GENESIS64 version 10.97.3 and prior and Mitsubishi Electric MC Works64 all versions. Allowing an authenticated attacker to disclose or tamper with confidential information and data contained in the products, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.</span></td>
<td style="width: 12.3754%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">7.8 - High</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 17.8571%;"><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-8299" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">CVE-2024-8299</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 68.937%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Uncontrolled Search Path Element vulnerability in ICONICS GENESIS64 all versions, Mitsubishi Electric GENESIS64 all versions and Mitsubishi Electric MC Works64 all versions allows a local authenticated attacker to execute a malicious code by storing a specially crafted DLL in the applications folder.</span></td>
<td style="width: 12.3754%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">7.8 - High</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 17.8571%;"><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-8300" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">CVE-2024-8300</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 68.937%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Dead Code vulnerability in </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">ICONICS GENESIS64 </span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">version 10.97.2, 10.97.2 CFR1, 10.97.2 CRF2 and 10.97.3 and </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Mitsubishi Electric GENESIS64</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> version 10.97.2, 10.97.2 CFR1, 10.97.2 CRF2 and 10.97.3 allowing an authenticated attacker to execute a malicious code by tampering with a specially crafted DLL.</span></td>
<td style="width: 12.3754%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">7.0 - High</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 17.8571%;"><a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-9852" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">CVE-2024-9852</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 68.937%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Uncontrolled Search Path Element vulnerability in </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">ICONICS GENESIS64</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> all versions, </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Mitsubishi Electric GENESIS64</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> all versions and </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Mitsubishi Electric MC Works64</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> all versions allows a local authenticated attacker to execute a malicious code and elevation of privileges by storing a specially crafted DLL in a specific folder.</span></td>
<td style="width: 12.3754%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">7.8 - High</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Table 1. CVEs found in ICONICS Suite.</span></p>
<p>ICONICS Suite is a SCADA solution suite that has <a href="https://iconics.com/en-us/News/Press-Releases/2024/ICONICS-Releases-Version-10-97-3-of-ICONICS-Suite" target="_blank" rel="noopener">hundreds of thousands of installations in over 100 countries</a>. This suite is commonly used in critical infrastructure sectors such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Government</li>
<li>Military</li>
<li>Manufacturing</li>
<li>Water and wastewater</li>
<li>Utilities &amp; Energy</li>
</ul>
<p>On unpatched ICONICS installations without any workarounds or remediations, these vulnerabilities could lead to escalation of privileges, DoS and in specific circumstances, even full system compromise:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Attackers could perform </strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/dll-hijacking-techniques/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>DLL hijacking</strong></a>, by substituting legitimate ICONICS DLL files with malicious DLL files that have the legitimate files' names. This could potentially lead to arbitrary code execution, system integrity compromise and persistent attacker access.</li>
<li><strong>Attackers could escalate their privileges</strong>, gaining unauthorized access to restricted resources, executing malicious actions or even causing a DoS on the affected system.</li>
<li><strong>Attackers could manipulate critical files</strong>, modifying configuration settings or replacing legitimate binaries with malicious ones. This could potentially result in unauthorized access, data manipulation, elevation of privileges, trust relationship abuse or even full system compromise.</li>
<li>In combination, these vulnerabilities pose a risk to the confidentiality, integrity and availability of a system.</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed in this post with the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/zero-trust-ot-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Industrial OT Security</a> is the Palo Alto Networks operational technology (OT) solution with security services that work within our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a> (NGFW).</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR </a>and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a> detect known and novel DLL hijacking attacks.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cloud" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Cloud</a> can assist in identifying malware that uses DLL hijacking techniques.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XPANSE" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Xpanse</a> can also provide customer visibility into externally exposed OT services and devices.</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/vulnerabilities/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Vulnerabilities</b></a></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-138563-_wven14kmgum2"></a>Technical Analysis</h2>
<p>ICONICS Suite is used in numerous OT applications, including automation, data analysis and industrial internet of things (IIoT)/cloud integration. The following analysis details vulnerabilities discovered within the ICONICS Suite versions 10.97.2 and 10.97.3 for Windows platforms, which can compromise its effectiveness and security.</p>
<p>ICONICS Suite features a diverse range of servers, including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Building Automation and Control Networks (BACnet) server: BACnet is a data protocol designed to enable communication between different electronic devices (e.g., alarms, motion sensors, air conditioning units and heaters).</li>
<li>Open Platform Communications (OPC) servers: OPC servers are used to facilitate communication between various software and hardware components, particularly in automation and industrial control systems.</li>
<li>HTTP servers: HTTP servers provide connectivity and remote monitoring capabilities.</li>
</ul>
<p>We found vulnerabilities in ICONICS Suite versions 10.97.2 and 10.97.3, and they may also exist in earlier versions. According to our telemetry from public internet scans, several dozen ICONICS servers are accessible from the internet, making them particularly vulnerable to attackers.</p>
<p>Figure 1 shows the welcome page for an installation of ICONICS Suite on a Windows host where it displays its version number.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138567" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138567" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138567 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-824628-138563-1.png" alt="Image 1 is two screenshots side by side. On the left is a screenshot of the ICONICS Suite software readme and user guide. A red arrow points to the version number on the bottom left of the screen. On the right side is a notepad document. The contents are many lines of code as well as the version number that is in the header section." width="900" height="406" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-824628-138563-1.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-824628-138563-1-786x355.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-824628-138563-1-1552x700.png 1552w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-824628-138563-1-768x347.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-824628-138563-1-1536x693.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138567" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Welcome page for an ICONICS Suite version 10.97.2 installation.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138563-_q1z7rx6dlc1m"></a>Incorrect Default Permissions Vulnerability in GenBroker32  CVE-2024-7587</h3>
<p>GENESIS64 is a suite of tools that helps establish connectivity with OT device protocols like <a href="https://www.ashrae.org/technical-resources/technical-faqs/question-51-what-is-bacnet" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BACnet</a> and <a href="https://www.se.com/us/en/faqs/FA168406/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Modbus</a>. It also facilitates communication with <a href="https://www.ptc.com/en/technologies/iiot/industrial-automation/opc" target="_blank" rel="noopener">OPC</a> servers.</p>
<p>OPC servers enable various software packages, serving as OPC clients, to retrieve data from a process control device, like a programmable logic controller (PLC) or a distributed control system. However, ICONICS requires a <a href="https://docs.iconics.com/V10.96/GENESIS64/Help/Com/Tools/Data/DATA10001002_GenBroker.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GenBroker communications utility</a> to communicate with legacy implementations of OPC servers.</p>
<p>GenBroker is part of the <a href="https://iconics.com/en-us/Products/GENESIS32" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GENESIS32</a> and <a href="https://iconics.com/en-us/Products/GENESIS64" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GENESIS64</a> software solutions. The GenBroker communications utility has a 32-bit version called GenBroker32 and a 64-bit version called GenBroker64.</p>
<p>GENESIS32 is currently at <a href="https://iconics.com/en-us/Site/Product-Trials/GENESIS32-Trial" target="_blank" rel="noopener">version 9.7</a> and contains the vulnerable GenBroker32 utility. For a variety of reasons, ICONICS recommends <a href="https://iconics.com/en-us/Resources/ICONICS-Blog/Why-Upgrading-to-GENESIS-Is-the-Way-to-Go" target="_blank" rel="noopener">using GENESIS64 instead</a>, and GENESIS64 uses the non-vulnerable GenBroker64 utility by default. Additionally, GenBroker32 should not be installed on top of GENESIS64.</p>
<p>However, a user could inadvertently add the vulnerable GenBroker32 utility during or after installing GENESIS64. This addition triggers permission changes in a critical directory containing key binaries and configuration files for the ICONICS Suite, resulting in overly permissive settings that grant system-wide user access to this directory.</p>
<p>Figure 2 shows the version of GENESIS32 we installed during our security assessment.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138569" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138569" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138569 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-831523-138563-2.png" alt="Image 2 is a screenshot of the version information for Genesis32. There are two tabs, General and About ICONICS Inc. A magenta arrow points to the product version, which is 9.7.300.00. The information also includes additional license information, available disk space, and physical memory." width="500" height="423" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-831523-138563-2.png 924w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-831523-138563-2-520x440.png 520w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-831523-138563-2-827x700.png 827w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-831523-138563-2-768x650.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138569" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Version information for GENESIS32 during our security assessment.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a id="post-138563-_wdt2nvzatre7"></a> In our security assessment, after installing version 10.97.2 of the ICONICS Suite, the configuration page offered an option to install GenBroker, even when GenBroker64 was already installed. This option is labeled GenBroker and actually installed the vulnerable GenBroker32 utility. This GenBroker option did not indicate that GenBroker64 was pre-installed or that it would install the 32-bit version.</p>
<p><a id="post-138563-_wdt2nvzatre7"></a> Users unaware of these details might inadvertently install GenBroker32. Figure 3 illustrates the associated GenBroker option available as an additional tool for an ICONICS Suite v10.97.2 installation on a Windows host.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138571" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138571" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138571 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-834790-138563-3.png" alt="Image 3 is a screenshot of the ICONICS Suite install options. Main Installation button. Additional Tools button. Additional Tools list. GenBroker is outlined in red. OPC servers. List of OPC servers. " width="800" height="587" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-834790-138563-3.png 1836w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-834790-138563-3-599x440.png 599w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-834790-138563-3-953x700.png 953w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-834790-138563-3-768x564.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-834790-138563-3-1536x1128.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138571" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Option to install Genbroker32 shown as GenBroker.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a id="post-138563-_6jxp4ghp7shu"></a> We used a Windows installer package editor named <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/msi/orca-exe" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Orca</a> to inspect the ICONICS MSI file that installs GenBroker32.</p>
<p><a id="post-138563-_3tdqfncajdne"></a> Figure 4 shows the GenBroker32 installer <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ICONICS GenBroker.msi</span> in Orca to view the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">LockPermissions</span> table.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138573" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138573" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138573 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-839814-138563-4.png" alt="Image 4 is a screenshot of the LockPermissions table in the program Orca of ICONICS General broker.MSI. On the left is a window where the user can click into different kinds of tables. The columns included in the pane on the right include LockObject, Table, Dom, User and Permission." width="800" height="979" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-839814-138563-4.png 1097w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-839814-138563-4-360x440.png 360w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-839814-138563-4-572x700.png 572w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-839814-138563-4-768x940.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138573" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. GenBroker32 installer in Orca viewing the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">LockPermissions</span> table.</figcaption></figure>
<p>As shown in Figure 4, all objects listed in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">LockPermissions</span> table can perform a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CreateFolder</span> operation and set the owner as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">everyone</span>. The third entry indicates the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ICONICS</span> directory under <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\ProgramData</span>, and this entry grants every user of the system the permission to read, write and modify the contents of that directory.</p>
<p>Further analysis revealed that this GenBroker32 installer performs a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SetSecurityFile</span> operation to set the discretionary access control list (DACL) as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Allow-Everyone</span> for the directory <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\ProgramData\ICONICS</span>.</p>
<p>Figure 5 shows a <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/procmon" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Process Monitor</a> display filtered to reveal the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SetSecurityFile</span> operations performed when we ran the GenBroker32 installer.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138575" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138575" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138575 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-842823-138563-5.png" alt="Image 5 a screenshot of the Process Monitor window that contains the ICONICS Suite installer files. The fourth row is highlighted." width="900" height="403" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-842823-138563-5.png 1678w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-842823-138563-5-786x352.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-842823-138563-5-1562x700.png 1562w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-842823-138563-5-768x344.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-842823-138563-5-1536x688.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138575" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Overly permissive <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SetSecurityFile</span> operation observed in Process Monitor.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a id="post-138563-_6c3h2fbw7zq3"></a> Figures 6 and 7 illustrate the changes caused by the installation of GenBroker32 using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.security/get-acl" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Get-Acl</a></span> utility in PowerShell. Figure 6 depicts the state before installing GenBroker32, where only the administrator user (zingbox) has full access. Figure 7 shows the modified access after installing GenBroker32, reflecting the full access granted to every logged user on the system.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138577" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138577" style="width: 622px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138577 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-846594-138563-6.png" alt="Image 6 is a screenshot of GenBroker before it modifies the access control list in PowerShell. " width="622" height="252" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138577" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Get-Acl</span> to view the access permissions of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\ProgramData\ICONICS</span> before installing GenBroker32.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_138579" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138579" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138579 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-849108-138563-7.png" alt="Image 7 is a screenshot of the modification by GenBroker of the ACL in PowerShell. " width="700" height="252" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-849108-138563-7.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-849108-138563-7-786x282.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-849108-138563-7-1920x690.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-849108-138563-7-768x276.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-849108-138563-7-1536x552.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138579" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Get-Acl</span> to view the access permissions of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\ProgramData\ICONICS</span> after installing GenBroker32.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\ProgramData\ICONICS</span> directory contains critical configuration, reporting and logging files for the ICONICS Suite. This directory also contains a binary that an administrator can execute to renew the products license. Moreover, the read, write and execute permissions on this directory expose the system to a wide array of attacks.</p>
<p>Figure 8 shows the content of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\ProgramData\ICONICS</span>, which includes sensitive files that an attacker can easily hijack if they have full access permissions to this directory, such as the access provided through GenBroker32.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138581" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138581" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138581 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-852811-138563-8.png" alt="Image 8 is a screenshot of the contents of the Program Data folder for ICONICS. There are many folders, files and shortcuts. " width="1000" height="736" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-852811-138563-8.png 1182w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-852811-138563-8-598x440.png 598w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-852811-138563-8-951x700.png 951w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-852811-138563-8-768x565.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138581" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Content of the directory <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\ProgramData\ICONICS</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138563-_ur2lvk4vryod"></a>DLL Hijacking in MMCFG Leading to Elevation of Privileges  CVE-2024-1182</h3>
<p>Phantom DLL hijacking is a cybersecurity attack method where an attacker takes advantage of the way applications load DLLs. Phantom DLL hijacking involves reintroducing an obsolete, non-existing or no longer used legitimate DLL back into the system.</p>
<p>The attacker modifies the obsolete DLL to perform malicious activities, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Arbitrary code execution</li>
<li>Persistence</li>
<li>System integrity compromise</li>
<li>Elevation of privileges</li>
</ul>
<p>By abusing the Windows DLL search order (shown in Figure 9), an attacker can place the malicious DLL in a directory where the system will eventually look for it and load it. More details on this method can be found in the Unit 42 post <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/dll-hijacking-techniques/#:~:text=In%20this%20technique%2C%20adversaries%20look%20for%20a%20vulnerable%20executable%20that%20attempts%20to%20load%20a%20DLL%20that%20simply%20doesn%27t%20exist%20(or%20is%20missing)%20due%20to%20an%20implementation%20bug.%20Then%2C%20attackers%20will%20plant%20a%20malicious%20DLL%20with%20the%20non%2Dexistent%20DLL%E2%80%99s%20filename%20in%20its%20expected%20location." target="_blank" rel="noopener">Intruders in the Library: Exploring DLL Hijacking</a> under the "Phantom DLL Loading" section.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138583" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138583" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138583 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-856265-138563-9.png" alt="Image 9 is a diagram of the Windows dynamic link library search order. The special search locations are DLL redirection, API sets, SxS manifest redirection, loaded-module list, known DLLs, package dependency graph of process. Standard search locations are application directory, System32, System, Windows, current directory and directories listed in PATH variable. " width="600" height="662" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-856265-138563-9.png 1856w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-856265-138563-9-399x440.png 399w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-856265-138563-9-634x700.png 634w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-856265-138563-9-768x847.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-856265-138563-9-1392x1536.png 1392w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138583" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Windows DLL search order.</figcaption></figure>
<p>During our security assessment, we discovered this vulnerability in the ICONICS Suite due to an outdated SMS software development kit (SDK) for <a href="https://www.derdack.com/message-master/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Derdack's Message Master</a>. This outdated Message Master SMS SDK at version 2.0 was developed by Derdack but has been deprecated for approximately 15 years with no ongoing support.</p>
<p>While no longer maintained, the Message Master SMS SDK is still integrated into the ICONICS Suite AlarmWorX MMX module. This module is responsible for facilitating SMS and pager alerts. When those applications use Message Master SMS SDK, they are exposed to the underlying vulnerabilities present in the Message Master SMS SDK.</p>
<p>Figure 10 shows version 2.0 in the About window of the Message Master SMS SDK.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138585" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138585" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138585 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-860261-138563-10.png" alt="Image 10 is a screenshot of the Message Master SMS SDK Configuration window and the About Message Master window that shows the Derrick logo, the copyright information and the version number. " width="700" height="371" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-860261-138563-10.png 1332w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-860261-138563-10-786x417.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-860261-138563-10-1321x700.png 1321w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-860261-138563-10-768x407.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138585" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMCfg.exe</span> (Message Master SMS SDK configuration application) version 2.0.</figcaption></figure>
<p>When a user initiates an ANSI modem, it starts the Memory Master configuration tool <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMCfg.exe</span>. This tool is integrated into the Pager Agent component of AlarmWorX64 MMX to facilitate the ANSI modem connections.</p>
<p>During execution, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMCfg.exe</span> attempts to load a file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">REVERB1.dll</span><em>.</em> However, due to improper DLL path specification and the absence of this DLL in the system directory, Windows eventually looks for this DLL in the current working directory.</p>
<p>An attacker can use the vulnerable <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMCfg.exe</span> file for DLL hijacking by placing a malicious DLL named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">REVERB1.dll</span> in a directory where the attacker has write and execute permissions. As a result, the attacker can elevate privileges on the system.</p>
<p>Figure 11 shows a Process Monitor view filtered to show <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CreateFile</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">LoadImage</span> operations performed by <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMCfg.exe</span> for the malicious DLL during our security assessment, resulting in arbitrary code execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138587" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138587" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138587 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-863686-138563-11.png" alt="Image 11 is a screenshot of the ProcessMonitor window for sysinternals[.]com. Inset into the screenshot is the Windows terminal showing the phantom DLL hijacking. " width="1000" height="612" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-863686-138563-11.png 2020w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-863686-138563-11-719x440.png 719w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-863686-138563-11-1144x700.png 1144w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-863686-138563-11-768x470.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-863686-138563-11-1536x940.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138587" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Process Monitor showing the results of phantom DLL hijacking using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mmcfg.exe</span>, resulting in elevation of privileges.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138563-_lj0xy4m5i9bm"></a>Dead Code Vulnerability and Uncontrolled Search Path Element Vulnerability in ICONICS GENESIS64  CVE-2024-8299, CVE-2024-8300, CVE-2024-9852</h3>
<p>Similar to the previously described vulnerability, we found multiple vulnerable processes generated by ICONICS GENESIS64 that could be exploited through phantom DLL hijacking, and attackers could exploit these processes for the following purposes:</p>
<ul>
<li>Persistence</li>
<li>Stealth</li>
<li>Trust relationship abuse</li>
<li>Deceiving Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) and monitoring systems</li>
</ul>
<p>Additionally, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MelSim2ComProc.exe</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMXCall_in.exe</span>, which are present in GENESIS64, are integrated within critical components of the ICONICS Suite such as AlarmWorX64 MMX that require administrator privileges to work. As a consequence, under some scenarios where AlarmWorX64 MMX invokes these applications, they will inherit administrator privileges. This makes AlarmWorX64 MMX vulnerable to the same type of DLL hijacking attack as the vulnerabilities previously described in CVE-2024-1182.</p>
<p>We confirmed that the following software components are vulnerable to phantom DLL hijacking through the following DLL file names:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MelSim2ComProc.exe</span> using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Sim2ComProc.dll</span>: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MelSim2ComProc.exe</span> relies on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Sim2ComProc.dll</span> in a directory at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Program Files\ICONICS\GENESIS64\Compnents\Communication</span>. However, since the DLL is not present in the system directories, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MelSim2ComProc.exe</span> eventually looks for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Communication\Sim2ComProc.dll</span> in the current working directory.</li>
<li>An attacker could place <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Sim2ComProc.dll</span> in a directory called Communication inside the current working directory, which the attacker has control and write access to, making the application load the attackers malicious DLL.</li>
<li>Figure 12 shows Process Monitor filtered to show a successful attempt at DLL hijacking for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MelSim2ComProc.exe</span> using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Sim2ComProc.dll</span> during our security assessment.</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_138589" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138589" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138589 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-868812-138563-12.png" alt="Image 12 is a screenshot of the ProcessMonitor window for sysinternals[.]com. The highlighted line is for Load Image operation." width="1000" height="518" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-868812-138563-12.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-868812-138563-12-786x407.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-868812-138563-12-1352x700.png 1352w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-868812-138563-12-768x398.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/word-image-868812-138563-12-1536x795.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138589" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. DLL hijacking of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MelSim2Com</span> using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Sim2ComProc.dll</span> shown in Process Monitor.</figcaption></figure>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMXCall_in.exe</span> using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">libdxxmt.dll</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">libsrlmt.dll</span>: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMXCall_in.exe</span> serves as a call in agent for AlarmWorX64 MMX. Due to improper DLL path specification, it looks for the missing <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">librarylibdxxmt.dll</span> or <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">libsrlmt.dll</span> files in the current working directory.</li>
<li>Attackers could place a malicious DLL named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">libdxxmt.dll</span> or <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">libsrlmt.dll</span> in the current working directory where <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMXCall_in.exe</span> is executed, to make the application load their malicious DLL.</li>
<li>Figure 13 shows Process Monitor filtered to show a successful attempt at DLL hijacking for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMXCall_in.exe</span> using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">libdxxmt.dll</span> during our security assessment.</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_138597" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138597" style="width: 786px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="size-medium wp-image-138597 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/F13-786x376.png" alt="Image 13 is a screenshot of the ProcessMonitor window for sysinternals[.]com. The highlighted line is for IRP_MJ_CREATE operation." width="786" height="376" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/F13-786x376.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/F13-768x367.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/F13.png 1200w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138597" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. DLL hijacking of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMXCall_in</span> using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">libdxmmt.dll</span> shown in Process Monitor.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 14 shows Process Monitor filtered to show a successful attempt at DLL hijacking for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMXCall_in.exe</span> using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">libsrlmt.dll</span> during our security assessment.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138599" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138599" style="width: 786px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="size-medium wp-image-138599 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/F14-786x389.png" alt="Image 14 is a screenshot of the ProcessMonitor window for sysinternals[.]com. It shows an array of malicious_dll files." width="786" height="389" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/F14-786x389.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/F14-768x380.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/F14.png 1000w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138599" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MMXCall_in - libsrlmt.dll</span> DLL hijacking.</figcaption></figure>
<p>We have been working in collaboration with the ICONICS security team to fix these issues. ICONICS has <a href="https://iconics.com/en-us/About/Security/CERT" target="_blank" rel="noopener">released security patches</a> to address these issues.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138563-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>People often overlook the possibility of attackers abusing privileged file system operations, regardless of the danger they can pose to systems running these processes, especially when these vulnerabilities are found in OT environments.</p>
<p>The discovery of vulnerabilities within the ICONICS Suite, as identified in versions 10.97.3 and earlier for Windows platforms, highlights the importance of robust security measures. Proactive measures can help mitigate these vulnerabilities and safeguard against potential exploitation.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks offers solutions such as the Industrial OT Security service, integrated with NGFW subscriptions. This service can detect and prevent malicious activities, including malicious artifacts in transit and anomalous command access to OT field devices.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/zero-trust-ot-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Industrial OT Security</a> is designed to:
<ul>
<li>Use machine learning techniques to detect abnormal behavior in engineering workstations and field devices</li>
<li>Raise alerts in the event of a compromised environment, based on anomalous command access</li>
<li>Integrate with <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSOAR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSOAR</a> to detect devices running a vulnerable version of the ICONICS Suite, becoming proactive with standardized, automated and enforceable processes</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM </a>are designed to:
<ul>
<li>Detect known and novel DLL hijacking attacks, using the new generic Analytics DLL Hijacking tag</li>
<li>Prevent the execution of known and unknown malware using Behavioral Threat Protection and machine learning based on the Local Analysis module</li>
<li>Protect against credential gathering tools and techniques using the new Credential Gathering Protection available from Cortex XDR 3.4</li>
<li>Cortex XDR Pro is designed to detect post-exploit activity, including credential-based attacks, with behavioral analytics</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cloud" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Cloud</a>:
<ul>
<li>When paired with XSIAM, Cortex Cloud is enabled to block malicious processes from operating within the cloud environment</li>
<li>Cortex Cloud is designed to prevent the execution of known and unknown malware using Behavioral Threat Protection and machine learning based on the Local Analysis module.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XPANSE" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Xpanse</a> is designed to:
<ul>
<li>Provide a complete, accurate and continuously updated inventory of all global internet-facing assets, including exposed OT services and devices</li>
<li>Enable discovery, evaluation and mitigation of cyberattack surface risks</li>
<li>Facilitate evaluation of supplier risk</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the<a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">UK: +44.20.3743.3660</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Asia: +65.6983.8730</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">India: 00080005045107</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138563-_570cbe1pdhwx"></a>Additional Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.mitsubishielectric.com/en/psirt/vulnerability/pdf/2024-004_en.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Multiple Vulnerabilities in GENESIS64TM and MC Works64 [PDF]</a>  Mitsubishi
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/ics-advisories/icsa-24-184-03" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ICSA-24-184-03</a>  ICS Advisory</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="https://www.mitsubishielectric.com/en/psirt/vulnerability/pdf/2024-008_en.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Information Disclosure, Information Tampering and Denial of Service (DoS) Vulnerability in GENESIS64TM and MC Works64 [PDF]</a>  Mitsubishi
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/ics-advisories/icsa-24-296-01" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ICSA-24-296-01</a>  ICS Advisory</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="https://www.mitsubishielectric.com/en/psirt/vulnerability/pdf/2024-010_en.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Multiple Vulnerabilities in GENESIS64TM and MC Works64 [PDF]</a>  Mitsubishi
<ul>

</li>

Abusing Symbolic Links on Windows [PDF]</a>  James Forshaw, Google Project Zero</li>

</ul>

                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/nvidia-cuda-toolkit-vulnerabilities/" title="Multiple Vulnerabilities Discovered in NVIDIA CUDA Toolkit" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="vulnerabilities-in-iconics-software-suite:related-resources:Multiple Vulnerabilities Discovered in NVIDIA CUDA Toolkit:read now">

                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/11_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of vulnerabilities like CVE-2025-0282, CVE-2025-0283. Digital representation of a global network with interconnected lines and nodes over a map, highlighting global connectivity and data exchange." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/11_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/11_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/11_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/11_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/11_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="vulnerabilities-in-iconics-software-suite:related-resources:Threat Brief: CVE-2025-0282 and CVE-2025-0283 (Updated Jan. 17):High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-01-17T00:30:13+00:00">January 16, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-brief-ivanti-cve-2025-0282-cve-2025-0283/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="vulnerabilities-in-iconics-software-suite:related-resources:Threat Brief: CVE-2025-0282 and CVE-2025-0283 (Updated Jan. 17)">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Threat Brief: CVE-2025-0282 and CVE-2025-0283 (Updated Jan. 17)</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/ivanti/" title="Ivanti" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="vulnerabilities-in-iconics-software-suite:related-resources:Threat Brief: CVE-2025-0282 and CVE-2025-0283 (Updated Jan. 17):Ivanti">Ivanti</a>

                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="vulnerabilities-in-iconics-software-suite:related-resources:AI Tool Identifies BOLA Vulnerabilities in Easy!Appointments:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-07-25T10:00:55+00:00">July 25, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/bola-vulnerabilities-easyappointments/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="vulnerabilities-in-iconics-software-suite:related-resources:AI Tool Identifies BOLA Vulnerabilities in Easy!Appointments">
                    <h4 class="post-title">AI Tool Identifies BOLA Vulnerabilities in Easy!Appointments</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/bola/" title="BOLA" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="vulnerabilities-in-iconics-software-suite:related-resources:AI Tool Identifies BOLA Vulnerabilities in Easy!Appointments:BOLA">BOLA</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/api-attacks/" title="API attacks" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="vulnerabilities-in-iconics-software-suite:related-resources:AI Tool Identifies BOLA Vulnerabilities in Easy!Appointments:API attacks">API attacks</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/bola-vulnerabilities-easyappointments/" title="AI Tool Identifies BOLA Vulnerabilities in Easy!Appointments" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="vulnerabilities-in-iconics-software-suite:related-resources:AI Tool Identifies BOLA Vulnerabilities in Easy!Appointments:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                    </div>
    </div>
    <div class="l-container bs__controls">
      <div class="bs__progress"><span></span></div>
      <div class="bs__navigation"> 
        <ul>
          <li> 
            <button id="prevButton"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/slider-arrow-left.svg" alt="Slider arrow"></button>
          </li>
          <li> 
            <button id="nextButton"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/slider-arrow-left.svg" alt="Slider arrow"></button>
          </li>
        </ul>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
 
        <div class="be-enlarge-modal" id="enlargedModal">
          <div class="be-enlarge-modal__wrapper"> 
            <figure> 
              <button class="close__modal" id="closeModal"> 
              <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/close-modal.svg" alt="Close button"></button>

    </section>
  </main>
<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			                 <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:400px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			                  <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:949px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

						</li>

							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42/threat-intelligence-partners"   role="link" title="Discover Threat Intelligence" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Threat Intel and Incident Response Services:Proactive Assessments:Incident Response:Transform Your Security Strategy:Discover Threat Intelligence">Discover Threat Intelligence</a>
						</li>

				</nav>

          </div>
        </div>
        <div class="footer-menu-nav__wrapper">
                      <h3 class="footer-menu-nav__title">Company</h3>

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.7.1' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

function noSell(event) {
    event.preventDefault();
   if (( typeof OneTrust != 'undefined') &&  (!!OneTrust)) {
       OneTrust.ToggleInfoDisplay();
    }else{
      var href = event.target.getAttribute('href');
        window.open(href, '_blank'); 
    }
}

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "CloudCortex" || referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "CloudCortex" || referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
    
    $( ".do-not-sell-link a" ).on( "click", function( event ) {
        noSell(event);
      });
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</body>
</html>
